STA_DESC: BRIERY CREEK LAKE UPPER END OF LAKE PRIN
SECTION_DE: Appomattox River from the head of tidal waters, and free flowing tributaries to the Appomattox River, to their headwaters, unless otherwise designated in this chapter.

Notes:
2014/2016 Cycle:  This waters are designated by WQS as Tier III waters.  

Bio 'FS' Two 2012 surveys with an average score of 81.0.  This station was surveyed as part of the Cowpasture River Tier III survey to determine water quality and benthic macroinvertebrate community conditions within the Simpson Creek watershed.  This stream had an exceptional benthic community and habitat.  The benthic community was very diverse and dominated by pollution sensitive organisms.  The watershed is within the Jefferson National Forest and dominated by forested land cover with some roads and hiking trails that appear to have minimal impact on the stream.  The eroded stream banks and sediment deposition appear to be from torrential flows in this high gradient watershed.  

Outside Data Window:  
Bio 'FS' One VSCI fall 2004 survey scoring 74.7.  This station was surveyed as part of the Cowpasture River Tier III survey to determine water quality and benthic macroinvertebrate community conditions within the Simpson Creek watershed.  This stream had an exceptional benthic community and habitat.  The benthic community was very diverse and was dominated by pollution sensitive organisms.

STA_DESC: SANDY RIVER RESERVOIR, MARROWBONE CR AR
SECTION_DE: Appomattox River from the head of tidal waters, and free flowing tributaries to the Appomattox River, to their headwaters, unless otherwise designated in this chapter.

Notes:
2016 Cycle:  2016 FULL DELIST Tempeerature (0/12).  E.coli (1/12) insufficient to assess but shown as 'OE'.  Initial Temp 303(d) Listing 2006.  The 2006 Integrated Report (IR) initially reported four temperature excursions of the Class VI 20 °C criterion from 19 measurements resulting in the original 303(d) Listing.  Temperature excursions occurred three times in the month of July (2000, 2003 & 2004) and September 2003.  The maximum exceedance, 21.6 °C, occurred on July 10, 2000.  

2012 Cycle:  No additional data beyond the 2008 IR.  Temperature impairment remains.  Three of 15 temperature measurements in 2008 and three of 12 measurements in 2010.  Exceedances occur in July '03 (20.1°C) & '04 (21.1°C) and Sept. '03 (21.2°C). 

Outside Data Window:  De-listed 2008 E.coli (2004 Bacteria FC Listed station. 2/18). Temp exceeds in July '03 & '04 (Max. 21.1 °C) and Sept. '03 (21.2°C); 2 RBP II surveys 2000; REF benthic site. AQ 2000 sediment.

STA_DESC: confluence of Johns Creek and LOtter Riv
Notes:
2008/2010/2012/2014/2016 Cycle:  Little Otter River Bacteria TMDL Study is U.S. EPA approved on 02/02/2001.  Fed ID 1547 / 9486 / 19639 / 24557 / 24780.  SWCB approved 6/17/2004.  Bacteria Implementation Plan SWCB approved 3/27/2007.  Originally 303(d) Listed 1996 for FC.

E.coli impairment is nested within the overall TMDL Study and Bacteria Implementation Plan. Fed ID: 24557 Little Otter River.  There are no additional E.coli data beyond the 2014 IR where two (350 and 900 cfu/100 ml) of four E.coli samples exceed the 235 cfu/100 ml instantaneous criterion.  


Bio initial Listing 2002 based on RBP II surveys.

Bio 'IM' 2016- Bio- 'IM' four VSCI surveys (2011 - 2012) with an average score of 49.4. The benthic community was dominated by midges (Chironomidae) and net-spinning caddisflies (Hydropsychidae).  These organisms typically dominate streams that have high amounts of organic matter.  Two surveys had low taxa richness and diversity and all had low numbers of pollution-sensitive taxa such as mayflies and stoneflies.  

Outside Data Window:
Bio 'IM' 2014- Bio- 'IM' Six VSCI surveys (2008 - 2012) with an average score of 48.5. The benthic community was dominated by midges (Chironomidae) and net-spinning caddisflies (Hydropsychidae).  These organisms typically dominate streams that have high amounts of organic matter.  Two surveys had low taxa richness and diversity and all had low numbers of pollution-sensitive taxa such as mayflies and stoneflies.  

Bio 'IM'- 2010 and 2012 data windows.  A 2008 Probabilistic stressed site.  Additional sampling in support of TMDL development.  DO, Temp, pH, TN- NH3-N and water column metals/toxics- 'IN'.  Single observation of escherichia coli (E.coli) does not exceed the instantaneous criterion but is insufficient to assess. 
Three VSCI surveys (2006-2008) with an average score of 44.20.  No PEC Sediment exceedances from 2008 data; metals only. 

Benthic Overall 2006 Status:  'IM' 1 VSCI survey (2006) scoring 40.7.  Listing based on previous RBP II surveys:  Bio- 'MI'; moderately impaired.  The 2004 IR reports two spring RBP II surveys scoring 73.68 (1999) and 35.00 (2000).  BPJ used in spring 1999 because the number of total taxa and total individuals were low, and pollution tolerant taxa were dominant.
BOR FC TMDL Study - Surface observations; FC stirred Bottom observations 2/2-W. Bacteria TMDL Study APPROVED 02/02/01.

Lake Gaston and the John Kerr Reservoir in Virginia and their tributaries in Virginia, unless otherwise designated in this chapter (not including the Roanoke or the Dan Rivers). The Roanoke River Service Authority's water supply intake is in this section

Notes:
2016 & 2018 Cycles:  Roanoke R. General Standard - Benthic (Sediment) TMDL Study US EPA approved 5/10/2006. FED ID: 33861.  SWCB approved 9/07/2006.  Mason Creek NESTED within TMDL watershed; nesting occurs with the 2014 IR.  Roanoke R. PCB TMDL Study US EPA approved 4/9/2010.  Fed ID: 38522.  SWCB approved 12/9/2010.  

Bio 'IM' Two 2013 VSCI surveys with an average score of 44.4.  The benthic community is dominated by pollution tolerant organisms, particularly Chironomidae (midges) in the spring and Hydropsychidae (net-spinning caddisfly) in the fall.  The watershed is in an urban setting with industrial, commercial and residential land uses.  Most of the habitat scores are in the optimal and sub-optimal range indicating that potential water quality problems are related to water chemistry rather than habitat limitations. 

Outside Data Window:  

2010 Assessment Bio 'IM' Three VSCI surveys (2004-2005) with an average score of 37.6.

Two VSCI surveys (2005) 'IM' scoring 37.1 Spring and 37.8 Fall.  This station surveyed at the request of citizen monitors (SOS).  The benthic community is dominated by pollution tolerant organisms.  Most of the habitat scores are in the optimal and sub-optimal range indicating that potential water quality problems are related to water chemistry rather than habitat limitations.  In April 2005, a fish kill occurred in the lower reaches of Mason Creek including this station.  The cause was an illegal discharge of chemicals used in manufacturing floor and drain cleaners.  

Supplemental Information:
4AMSN003.05- Bio 'IM' There are no additional data beyond the 2008 IR where three VSCI surveys (2004 - 2005) average score is 55.4.  The average VSCI score indicates the benthic community is impaired.  Most of the habitat scores are in the optimal and sub-optimal range indicating that potential water quality problems are related to water chemistry rather than habitat limitations. The 2010 IR reports Bio 'IM' Three VSCI surveys (2004 - 2005) average score is 55.4.

STA_DESC: NORTH MAYO AT GAGE NEAR SPENCER RT. 629
Notes:
2016 Cycle:  Dan River Bacteria TMDL U.S. EPA approved 12/08/2008.  Fed ID: 35754.  SWCB approved 4/28/2009.  Trend site.
4ANMR002.60 is a 1999 Federal Consent Decree Attachment B station for FC.  The station is not 303(d) Listed in 2002 as only one exceedance of the former 1000 cfu/100 ml instantaneous criterion is found from 21 samples.  Originally 303(d) Listed 2004 for FC.
2004 Bacteria Listed 3 / 25 - 'IM'. 2007 fish tissue finds no excursions of new WQS PCB 20 ppb TV and no metals excursions; no sediment collection made.

Outside Data Window:   2002 fish tissue no exceedances; sediment no PEC exceedances. If new PCB 20 ppb WQS criterion applied to 2002 fish tissue data 1 sp. Rainbow trout (2 fish; 30.1-40 cm) exceeds at 31.48 ppb. 
1999 fish tissue analysis finds arsenic (As) equaling the TSV of 0.072 ppm in sucker species at 0.72 ppm. 
1999 and 2000 sediment no excursions of the PEC SVs.
2008 IR- Total measurements 25.  Daily Mean Flow; 02070000 North Mayo R. - Spencer <7Q10 of 23 cfs @ gage on 6/19/02 (15 cfs) and 8/06/02 (10 cfs).  Two Fully Supporting field measurement sets excluded from the dataset.

STA_DESC: RT. 460/11 BRIDGE BELOW GREEN HILL, INC.
Notes:
2016 Cycle:  Roanoke R. Bacteria TMDL U.S. EPA approved 8/02/2006. Fed ID 24538.  SWCB approved 6/27/2007. NESTED 2008:  Fed ID: 24538, EPA approved 8/02/2006.   
The 2016 IR finds 2/12 E.coli samples in excess of the 235 cfu/100 ml criterion.  And 2/12 temperature exceedances from calendar 2014 data collections. These are the first new E.coli data resulting in continued Recreational Use impairment for the AU.
Outside Data Window:
This AU (VAW-L01R_RSF01A00) initially listed in 2004 for fecal coliform 3/18 exceedances at 4ARSF002.20.  Station 4ARSF000.88 E.coli data for 2012, 2010 and 2008 IRs find one of nine escherichia coli (E.coli) bacteria samples exceeds the 235 cfu/100 ml criterion at 300.  4ARSF000.88 data were insufficient to assess as impaired for E.coli for these cycles.  There were no additional data within the 2014 data window.

Application of new WQS TV (20 ppb) adds 2 more sp. Smallmouth bass (38.1-47.2 cm) at 40.41; largemouth bass (42.7-47.3 cm) at 26.96; and 2 additional flathead catfish (65.5 cm) at 50.67 and (60.5 cm) at 20.01 ppb.
2001- No exceedances from a total of 38 fish analyzed (former 54 ppb).  Application of New WQS TV (20 ppb) adds 2 sp. Smallmouth bass (45.7-53.1 cm) at 30.68, smallmouth bass (36.1-40.0 cm) at 24.5 ppb and white sucker (40.4-45.0 cm) at 21.8 ppb.
